verses.verse: (1 He exhorteth2 to that worship which is acceptable to God,9 to love unfained, 14, 20 even towards our enemies.) I Beseech (The fourth part of this Epistle, which after the finishing of the chief points of Christian doctrine, consisteth in declaring of precepts of Christian life. And first of all he giveth general precepts and grounds: the chiefest whereof is this that every man consecrate himself wholly to the spiritual service of God, and do as it were sacrifice himself, trusting to the grace of God.) you therefore brethren, (By this preface he showeth that God’s glory is the utmost end of all our doings.) by the mercies of God, that ye (In times past the sacrifices were presented before the altar, but now the altar is everywhere.) give up your (Yourselves: in times past, other bodies than our own, now our own must be offered.) bodies a (In times past, dead sacrifices were offered, but now we must offer such as have the spirit of life in them.) living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your (Spiritual.) reasonable serving of God.

(The second precept is this, That we take not other men’s opinions or manners for a rule of life, but that we wholly renouncing this world, set before us as our mark, the will of God, as it is manifested and opened unto us in his word.) And fashion not yourselves like unto this world, but be ye changed by the renewing of your (Why then there is no place left for reason, which the heathen Philosophers place as a Queen in a Castle, nor for man’s free will, which the Popish Schoolmen dream on, if the mind must be renewed. See Eph. 1:18 and 2:5 and 4:17 and Col. 1:21.) mind, that ye may (Cross references: : Eph. 5:17; 1 Thess. 4:3) prove what that good, and acceptable and perfect will of God is.

(Thirdly he admonisheth us very earnestly, that every man keep himself within the bounds of his vocation, and that every man be wise according to the measure of grace that God hath given him.) For I (I charge.) say through the grace that is given unto me, to everyone that is among you, that no man (That he please not himself too much, as they do, which persuade themselves they know more than indeed they do.) presume to understand above that which is meet to understand, but that he understand according to (We will be sober if we take not that upon us, which we have not, and if we brag not of that we have.) sobriety, as God hath dealt to every man the (1 Cor. 12:11; Eph. 4:7) measure of (By faith he meaneth the knowledge of God in Christ, and the gifts which the holy Ghost poureth upon the faithful.) faith.

(There is a double reason of the precept going afore: the one is because God hath not committed everything to be done of every man: and therefore, he doeth backwardly, and not only unprofitably, but also to the great disprofit of others, wearieth himself and others, which passeth the bounds of his vocation: the other is, for that this diversity and inequality of vocations and gifts, redoundeth to our commodity seeing that the same is therefore instituted and appointed, that we should be bound one to another. Whereupon it followeth that no man ought to be grieved thereat, seeing that the use of every private gift is common.) For as we have many members in one body, and all members have not one office,
So we being many, are one body in Christ, and every one, one anothers members.

(1 Pet. 4:10) (That which he spake before in general, he applieth particularly to the holy functions, wherein men offend with greater danger. And he divideth them into two sorts, to wit, into Prophets, and Deacons, and again he divideth the Prophets into doctors, and Pastors. And of Deacons he maketh three sorts: to wit, the one to be such as are (as it were) treasurers of the Church coffers, whom he calleth properly Deacons: the other to be the governors of discipline, who are called Seniors or Elders: the third to be such as properly served in the help of the poor, of which sort the company of widows were.) Seeing then that we have gifts that are divers, according to the grace that is given unto us, whether we have prophecy, let us prophesy according to the (That every man observe the measure of that which is revealed unto him.) portion of faith.
Or an office, let us wait on the office: or he that (Whose office only is to expound the Scriptures.) teacheth, on teaching:

Or he that (Who in other places is called the Pastor.) exhorteth, on exhortation: he that (To wit, the alms, that he distribute them faithfully, and without respect of person.) distributeth, let him do it (Matt. 6:2; 2 Cor. 9:7) with simplicity: he that (The Elders of the Church.) ruleth, with diligence: he that (They that are busied about tending on the poor, must do it with cheerfulness, lest they add sorrow to sorrow.) showeth mercy, with cheerfulness.

(Now he cometh to the duties of the second Table, which he deriveth from charity, which is as it were the fountain of them all. And he defineth Christian charity by sincerity, hatred of evil, earnest study of good things, good affection to help our neighbor, and whose final end is, the glory of God.) Let love be without dissimulation. (Amos 5:15) Abhor that which is evil, and cleave unto that which is good.
(Eph. 4:2; 1 Pet. 2:17) Be affectioned to love one another with brotherly love. In giving honor, go one before another.
Not slothful to do service, fervent in spirit (This piece is well put in, for it maketh difference between Christian duties, and Philosophical duties.) serving the Lord,

(He reckoneth up divers other virtues together with their effects, to wit, hope, patience in tribulation, equanimity, continuance in prayer, liberality towards the saints, hospitality, moderation of mind, even in helping our enemies, a selfsame feeling with others as well in adversity as prosperity, modesty, endeavor to maintain honest concord so nigh as we may with all men, which cannot be extinguished by any man’s injuries.) Rejoicing in hope, patient in tribulation, (1 Pet. 5:8) continuing in prayer.

(Luke 18:1; 1 Cor. 16:1) (A true rule of charity, when we are no less touched with other men’s wants, than with our own, and having that feeling, help them as much as we can.) Distributing unto the (Not upon pleasure, and needless duties, but upon necessary uses.) necessities of the Saints: (Heb. 13:2; 1 Pet. 4:13) giving yourselves to hospitality.
(Matt. 5:44) Bless them which persecute you: bless, I say, and curse not.
Rejoice with them that rejoice, and weep with them that weep.

Be like affectioned one towards another: (Prov. 3:7; Isa. 5:21) be not high-minded: but make yourselves equal to them of the (There is nothing that doth so much break concord as ambition, when as every man loatheth a base estate, and seeketh ambitiously to be aloft.) lower sort: be not (Be not puffed up, with opinion of your own wisdom.) wise in yourselves.
(Prov. 20:22; Matt. 5:39; 2 Cor. 8:11; 1 Pet. 3:9) Recompense to no man evil for evil: procure things honest in the sight of all men.
(Heb. 12:14) If it be possible, as much as in you is, have peace with all men.
Dearly beloved, (Eccl. 2:18; Matt. 5:39) avenge not yourselves, but give place unto wrath: for it is written, (Deut. 32:35; Heb. 10:30) Vengeance is mine: I will repay, saith the Lord.

(Prov. 24:22) Therefore if thine enemy hunger, feed him: if he thirst, give him drink: for in so doing thou shalt heap (After this sort doth Solomon point out the wrath of God which hangeth over a man.) coals of fire on his head.
Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with goodness.
